Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Accelerated Catalytic Design and Characterization (ACDC)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research. This planning grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Engineering Research Center at the International Institute for Nanotechnology at Northwestern University that brings together a transdisciplinary team of researchers, educators, and stakeholders focused on the invention and development of new methodologies to dramatically accelerate materials discovery and design. Utilizing combinatorial nanoscience implemented in mega-libraries (libraries with billions of systematically varied particle compositions and sizes) for the rapid discovery and development of materials, critical for hydrogen production and utilization to create a cleaner, cheaper energy; nitrogen fixation to enhance food production; and water purification to yield access to clean water at lower cost and greater scale. The methodologies developed are likely to have applicability far beyond the catalytic solutions to societal needs recognized here.

The planning activities will help develop a highly integrated convergent team within a framework of diversity and inclusion. The research mission will be sharpened into a crisp, singular vision for a successful ERC that has the potential to address significant societal needs. World leaders in the three key topical areas, water, food and energy, have been identified and the exchange of ideas that will occur in open symposia at which these individuals will participate will generate new ideas for exploiting the combinatorial approach. The knowledge gained through the advancement of this planning grant will be a benefit for all the participants, particularly the graduate students and postdoctoral scholars who will be highly involved in the full proposal preparation. Beyond the fields of nanoscience and catalysis, new knowledge about how best to facilitate and enhance convergent research will be discovered.

This ERC Planning Grant will enable meaningful partnerships between academia, industry, and affiliated stakeholders to be developed and increase the potential for productive collaborations. The proposed planning activities will also enhance the infrastructure for future convergent research efforts and lay a foundation for innovative educational programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project convened a broad cross-section of stake-holders to generate creative technical approaches for exploiting nanoscale materials to achieve global sustainability. Two workshops, both of which followed established practices in team science, were held. A key objective of the first workshop was the creation of a framework for a competitive ERC proposal. The second workshop was more broadly aimed at brainstorming ideas for future large-center proposals. In both, conference participants integrated knowledge, methods, and expertise from different disciplines to as to generate novel insights for catalyzing scientific discovery and innovation. Furthermore, participants developed a shared vision for the significant societal need in sustainable energy, and an appreciation for the many disciplines, beyond materials and catalysis, that can contribute to the solution. The format of the workshops, which included oral presentations, a poster session, and a moderated Q&A session, was designed to ensure that all opinions and voices were heard, without regards to seniority. Furthermore, the participants were selected to reflect the broad diversity of the US population.

Broader Impacts

The planning activities supported by this award gave the participants a deep understanding of the meaning and significance of convergent research. The PIs have a greater appreciation of the complexity of leading a team of researchers from diverse disciplines to solve a societal grand challenge via a single, exemplary engineered device. Furthermore, all participants have increased their awareness of unconscious bias via the format of the workshops, which explicitly tackled the default image of who is qualified to perform cutting edge research. In the later stages of the award, support was provided to expand efforts in diversity and inclusion via the program ?Women Supporting Women in the Sciences,? an international initiative bringing together graduate and professional-level women and allies in science, technology, engineering to mentor each other and mentor younger girls to pursue STEM careers (https://ws2global.org/). Postdoctoral scholar, Jill Wenderott, leads this effort. The experience has given her exceptional professional development opportunities, including successful proposal submission to the American Physical Society, as she prepares for her independent faculty career.
